title: Understanding the Influence of Power Transformer Faults on the Frequency Response Signature Using Simulation Analysis and Statistical Indicators

authors.name: Salem Mgammal Al-Ameri
affiliations: Tun Hussein Onn University of Malaysia

authors.name: M. S. Kamarudin
affiliations: Tun Hussein Onn University of Malaysia

authors.name: Mohd Fairouz Mohd Yousof
affiliations: Tun Hussein Onn University of Malaysia

authors.name: Ali Ahmed Salem
affiliations: Tun Hussein Onn University of Malaysia

abstract: Frequency Response Analysis (FRA) is the most reliable technique currently used to evaluate the mechanical integrity of power transformers. While the measurement devices have been well developed over the past two decades, interpretation of the FRA signatures is still challenging regardless of the several papers published in this regard. This paper adds an attempt to understand the power transformer FRA signatures through experimental and simulation analyses. In this context, experimental FRA measurements are conducted on a 33/11 kV, 30 MVA transformer under various faults, including winding deformation, the short circuit turns, loss of clamping, and bushing fault. At the same time, the high-frequency transformer model that comprises series capacitance, self-inductance, series resistance, and mutual inductance is simulated using MATLAB / Simulink to compare simulation and experimental results. The correlation between physical circuit parameters and various faults facilitates a better understanding of each fault’s effect on the FRA signature. To quantify the impact of such faults, correlation coefficient, the absolute sum of logarithmic error, standard deviation, and sum square error are calculated with respect to the healthy signature at three frequency regions. Results show that using statistical coefficients over three frequency ranges of the FRA signature facilitates better fault identification and quantification.

Mohd Fairouz Mohd Yousof (fairouz@uthm.edu.my)
ABSTRACT Frequency Response Analysis (FRA) is the most reliable technique currently used to evaluate
the mechanical integrity of power transformers. While the measurement devices have been well developed
over the past two decades, interpretation of the FRA signatures is still challenging regardless of the several
papers published in this regard. This paper adds an attempt to understand the power transformer FRA sig-
natures through experimental and simulation analyses. In this context, experimental FRA measurements are
conducted on a 33/11 kV , 30 MV A transformer under various faults, including winding deformation, the short
circuit turns, loss of clamping, and bushing fault. At the same time, the high-frequency transformer model that
comprises series capacitance, self-inductance, series resistance, and mutual inductance is simulated using
MATLAB / Simulink to compare simulation and experimental results. The correlation between physical
circuit parameters and various faults facilitates a better understanding of each fault’s effect on the FRA
signature. To quantify the impact of such faults, correlation coefﬁcient, the absolute sum of logarithmic
error, standard deviation, and sum square error are calculated with respect to the healthy signature at three
frequency regions. Results show that using statistical coefﬁcients over three frequency ranges of the FRA
signature facilitates better fault identiﬁcation and quantiﬁcation.
INDEX TERMS Power transformer, frequency response analysis, fault diagnosis, statistical indicators.

I. INTRODUCTION
Power transformer is an essential component in the electric-
ity grids. While transformer is designed to withstand harsh
mechanical and electrical stresses, natural aging, deteriora-
tion of solid insulation, severe short circuit faults, earth-
quakes, and careless transportation may lead to winding and
core deformation. As such, several condition monitoring and
fault diagnostic techniques have been developed over the
years to maintain transformer reliability. For instance, insu-
lating oil analysis can provide considerable information about
the health state of the transformer and its useful remaining
lifetime [1]. Dynamic resistance measurement used to diag-
nose the transformer tap changer [2]. Partial discharge mea-
surement is used to assess the condition of power transformer
bushings and insulation systems [3], [4].
Currently, Frequency response analysis (FRA) is an ofﬂine
technique using a well-developed frequency analyzer to eval-
uate the mechanical integrity of power transformers [5]. The
FRA technique can detect several mechanical core and wind-
ing deformations within power transformers. FRA technique
can also be used to detect the degradation of the dielectric
insulation system [6], [7]. Mechanical and electrical faults
result in changes in the winding resistance, inductance, and
capacitance, and hence the winding impedance or transfer
function will be changed within a particular frequency range.
The FRA measurement is conducted ofﬂine without any
power electronic interface and hence the issue of mirror
frequency discussed in [8] is insigniﬁcant. The presented
data include magnitude and phase spectrum. Results can be
saved as an excel ﬁle that captures complete data. In case of
failed measurement, it can be repeated on site in few minutes.
Hence lack of data as discussed in [9] is irrelevant to the FRA
technique.
FRA is a two-response graphical comparison technique in
which the measured frequency response is compared with
the transformer ﬁngerprint. This comparison is usually con-
ducted visually or by using statistical indicators [10], [11].
However, consistent interpretation of FRA signatures is still
challenging due to the lack of widely accepted FRA codes.
This is attributed to the fact that staging real faults on oper-
ating transformers to investigate their impacts on the FRA
signature is impractical. On the other hand, lack of resources
has limited research efforts on custom-made transformers that
can be used for experimental studies. Most research activities
in this ﬁeld have been conducted using simulation analysis
on transformer models.
FIGURE 1. 33/11 kV 30MVA measured transformer (a) Onsite sister
transformer (b) HV-LV windings, top view.
Finite element methods (FEM) are used to mimic physical
systems like power transformers, but it calls for a high-speed
computer. State-space or transfer function is a technique that
can model the transformer analytically based on a set of
ﬁrst-order differential equations [12]–[14]. Also, a lumped
equivalent circuit can represent the transformer winding in
a high-frequency range [15], [16]. Relevant literature on
understanding the effect of transformer FRA signature is
summarized in Table 1.
The above discussion reveals that, there is no single paper
investigated all kinds of faults through comprehensive exper-
imental, modelling and analytical approaches. This paper is
aimed to explore the impact of several faults on the trans-
former FRA signature through comprehensive simulation and
experimental analyses. In this regard, six common trans-
former faults including inter-disk fault, axial displacement,
radial deformation, bushing fault, loss of clamping pressure,
and short circuit fault are investigated. The FRA signature
for each fault is obtained and analyzed using four statistical
indicators. The study is performed on real 33/11 kV , 30 MV A
transformer data. MATLAB Simulink is used to simulate
the circuit model corresponding to each fault. Results are
analyzed using various numerical indices such as, correlation
coefﬁcient (CC), Absolute sum of logarithmic error (ASLE),
standard deviation (SD), and sum square error (SSE).
II. MODEL DEVELOPMENT
Experimental and simulation analyses are conducted on a
33/11 kV , 30 MV A transformer shown in Figure 1. The
geometrical dimensions are used to identify the transformer
equivalent circuit parameters based on the procedure shown
in Figure 2. The simulation model is ﬁrstly validated by
comparing the simulation and measured FRA signatures of
the investigated transformer. After that, different faults of
various levels are simulated by changing equivalent circuit
parameters, as will be elaborated below.
A. TRANSFORMER WINDING GEOMETRY
Figure 3a shows the insulation thickness between discs ti. The
investigated transformer high voltage (HV) winding com-
prises 96 discs per phase, 30 turns each as shown in Fig-
ures 3 and 4. The low voltage (LV) winding has 25 parallel

B. CALCULATION OF CIRCUIT PARAMETERS
Transformer modeling for frequency response analysis stud-
ies calls for calculating the total series capacitance Cs,
the capacitance between turns Ct and discs Cd , winding series
resistance Rs, capacitance to the ground Cg, conductance Gs,
and self and a matrix Mkm representing the self (main diagonal
elements) and mutual inductance (off-diagonal elements).
1) SERIES CAPACITANCE
The capacitances between turns, Ct , and discs Cd are shown
in Figure 6. The transformer capacitance equivalent circuit is
shown in Figure 7, which can be calculated using (1). The
capacitance between adjacent discs is shown in Figure 6b.
It can be calculated using (2) in which d is the distance
between turns (accounting for the fringing effect) and di and
do are the winding’s inner and outer diameters, respectively.

3) SELF AND MUTUAL INDUCTANCES
The self and mutual inductances can be calculated using a
matrix generated by (10), (11) [28].

Mkm represents the mutual inductance between discs k and
m, r is the average radius of the discs, and z is the axial
distance between the two discs. Nk and Nm are the numbers of
turns in the kth and mth sections, as shown in Figure 8. K and
E are the elliptic integrals of the ﬁrst and second kinds. For
self-inductance when k =m, z is calculated by z =0.2235
×(h+w). Also, h1 and w1 are like h2 and w2. The diagonal
elements of the obtained matrix represent the self-inductance,
while the off-diagonal elements are the mutual inductance
between discs. In this study, the value of r and αare assumed
to be equal because the average radius of the sections is the
same. The value of the magnetic permeability of the medium
is µ0=4π×10−7 H/m. The self and mutual inductance uses
the same equation because they are of the same concept. The
self-inductance is for the turns in the same phase, whereas the
mutual inductance is the inductance between the HV and LV
windings.
C. EQUIVALENT CIRCUIT MODEL
The equivalent circuit of a single disc comprising the above
parameters is shown in Figure 9 with a full circuit model as
shown in Figure 10.
The sensitivity of the FRA signature due to various faults
and variations of the model parameters is investigated below.
In all simulations, a sinusoidal excitation voltage of a 10 V
peak amplitude and sweep frequency range (10Hz to 2MHz)
is used as a source to plot the winding FRA signatures [20].
III. RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
The calculated parameters of the equivalent circuit shown
in Figure 10 are listed in Table 3.
FIGURE 9. Single-disc transformer winding components.
FIGURE 10. Transformer winding electrical circuit model.
The measured response is obtained for phase-A of a
33/11 kV , 30 MV A transformer using end−to −end open cir-
cuit conﬁguration. The measurement is conducted by inject-
ing the excitation signal at one terminal of phase-A of the
HV winding and measuring the response at the other terminal
while the LV windings are left open circuit.
The measured and simulated FRA signatures for the inves-
tigated transformer (phase-A) with no faults are shown
in Figure 11. While there is an apparent difference between
the two signatures, the two responses show similar trends in
terms of negative and positive slopes along with a reasonable
agreement of the resonance and anti-resonance points. It is
to be noted that FRA is a comparative analysis technique in
which correct conclusions can be reported as long as mea-
VOLUME 9, 2021 70939

TABLE 3. Electrical components of the circuit model.
FIGURE 11. Measured and simulated frequency response of the tested
transformer winding.
suring conﬁguration, circuit model, and operating conditions
are maintained the same during the reference and future FRA
measurements. Thus, using the simulation response shown
in Figure 11 as a model ﬁngerprint in the below investigation
is reasonable.
A. MODEL SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS
This analysis is performed by changing the winding RLC
values and investigating the impact of this change on the
FRA signature. This helps understand the effect of parameters
variations due to various faults, as shown in Table 4, on the
FRA signature.
The series resistance Rshv and Rslv are increased by 50% to
investigate its impact on the FRA signature, as shown in Fig-
ure 12. Resistance increase can be due to tap changer dam-
ages [30]. Results show that increasing the winding resistance
affects the response over the entire frequency range (20 Hz to
2 MHz). The response magnitude decreases at 80 kHz from
−76 dB to −84 dB and at 180 kHz from −82 dB to −92 dB.
On the other hand, the response is shifting towards lower fre-
quencies at frequencies above 100 kHz. The anti-resonance
frequency at 180 kHz is shifted to 130 kHz. It can be
concluded that increasing winding resistance decreases the
FIGURE 12. Effect of increasing resistance on the FRA signature.
TABLE 4. Transformer faults and winding parameters [20], [29].
response magnitude and shifts the resonant points towards
lower frequencies.
By increasing the self-inductance Lshv and Lslv by 50%,
the obtained FRA signature compared to the ﬁngerprint is
as shown in Figure 13. The increase in winding inductance
causes a signiﬁcant deviation in the low-frequency range
at which inductive components dominate the response. The
anti-resonance frequency at 180 kHz is shifted to 125 kHz
with a slight change in the magnitude. Such changes in the
inductance may be due to short circuit faults or core defor-
mation.
When the winding series capacitance Cshv and Cslv is
increased by 50%, the FRA signature shown in Fig-
ure 14 is obtained. This change causes the response to shift
towards lower frequencies with a reduction in the magnitude.
At 180 kHz, the anti-resonance frequency moves to 152 kHz.
On the other hand, the magnitude at the resonance frequency
250 kHz is reduced from −58 dB to −64 dB. The increase in
the series capacitance is mainly due to transformer insulation
aging as shown in Table 4.
B. FAULTS SIMULATION
In this section, various faults are simulated on the transformer
model shown in Figure 10 by changing particular circuit
parameters. The effect of each fault on the transformer FRA
signature is then investigated.
1) INTER-DISC FAULT
The inter-disc fault occurs due to considerable mechanical
stress on the discs, which causes variation in the axial disc
70940 VOLUME 9, 2021
S. M. A. N. Al-Ameriet al.: Understanding Influence of Power Transformer Faults on Frequency Response Signature
FIGURE 13. Effect of increasing inductance on the FRA signature.
FIGURE 14. Effect of increasing capacitance on the FRA signature.
FIGURE 15. Effect of inter-disc fault on the FRA signature.
spacing. As a result of the inter-disc fault, the total number
of operating discs is reduced. Accordingly, the inter-disc
fault can be simulated by reducing the number of discs
(10% reduction is assumed in this case study). FRA results
shown in Figure 15 reveal no signiﬁcant changes of the
resultant FRA signature from the ﬁngerprint in the fre-
quency range below 2 kHz. The response between 2 kHz
and 70 kHz is slightly shifted towards higher frequencies.
The peak magnitude also increases in the high-frequency
region.
2) AXIAL DISPLACEMENT FAULT
The change 1h shown in Figure 16 represents the
axial displacement that occurs due to the action of
two unequal axial electromagnetic force components on
FIGURE 16. Winding axial displacement configuration.
FIGURE 17. Winding axial displacement lumped circuit.
the LV winding. According to [20], axial displacement
can be simulated by changing the capacitance value
between the HV and LV windings CHL and the mutual
inductance Mkm.
This fault is simulated by increasing C HL by 10% while
reducing Mkm by10%. Figure 17 shows the circuit model with
LV winding exhibiting downward axial displacement fault.
Figure 18 shows the impact of this fault on the FRA signature
of which a small effect can be observed in the high-frequency
region. At this range, the magnitude increases from −78 dB
to −76 dB at 80 kHz.
3) RADIAL FAULT
Radial fault, also called radial buckling, is resulted due to
generated electromagnetic force from the circumferential
winding currents. Figure 19 shows the HV winding radial
VOLUME 9, 2021 70941
S. M. A. N. Al-Ameriet al.: Understanding Influence of Power Transformer Faults on Frequency Response Signature
FIGURE 18. Effect of axial displacement on the FRA signature.
FIGURE 19. Winding fault configuration.
FIGURE 20. Effect of radial fault on transformer FRA signature.
fault conﬁguration, which changes the width 1w. Accord-
ing to [29], [31], a minor radial winding fault can be sim-
ulated by decreasing the ground capacitance Cg by 10%.
The capacitance CHL and mutual inductance Mkm between
the HV and LV windings will also be decreased due to
the fault. As such, this fault is simulated by reducing the
HV winding ground capacitance Chg, CHL, and Mkm by
10% each.
The FRA signature shown in Figure 20 reveals that radial
fault alters the FRA signature in the mid-and high-frequency
ranges. It can be observed that, at 80 kHz, the magnitude
increases from −78 dB to −74 dB. The magnitude also
increases at all resonance and anti-resonance frequencies in
the high-frequency region.
FIGURE 21. Laboratory capacitance measurement for equivalent 33/11kV
transformer HV-winding bushing.
FIGURE 22. Transformer HV-winding bushing circuit model.
FIGURE 23. Effect of bushing fault on the FRA signature.
4) HV-WINDING BUSHING FAULT
An additional T-circuit is modeled and connected to the
proposed transformer equivalent circuit to model the HV
winding bushing [20]. The capacitances of this T-circuit are
measured for an equivalent transformer in the laboratory
using the setup shown in Figure 21. The equivalent circuit
is shown in Figure 22.
Bushing fault is simulated by a 50% reduction in the
bushing capacitance, i.e., from 29.43 pF to 14.72 pF.
Figure 23 shows that the magnitude of the FRA signature
increases in the high-frequency range above 200 kHz due to
bushing fault.
70942 VOLUME 9, 2021
S. M. A. N. Al-Ameriet al.: Understanding Influence of Power Transformer Faults on Frequency Response Signature
FIGURE 24. Effect of loss of clamping pressure on the FRA signature.
FIGURE 25. Electrical circuit model with shorted turns.
5) LOSS OF CLAMPING PRESSURE
Loss of clamping pressure is a common problem in old
transformers due to the severe degradation of the solid
insulation mechanical strength. This fault can be simu-
lated by increasing the value of the shunt conductance
Gsh [20]. Hence, this fault is simulated by increasing the shunt
conductance G sh−HV ,GHL , andG sh−LV by 50%. Figure 24
shows this fault affects the magnitude of the FRA signa-
ture with no obvious effect on the location of the resonance
frequencies.
FIGURE 26. Effect of short circuit fault on the FRA signature.
FIGURE 27. Correlation coefficient for various transformer faults within
three sub-frequency ranges.
6) SHORT CIRCUIT FAULT
A short circuit fault occurs due to damages in the winding
insulation, which causes a reduction in the total number of
winding turns. According to [32], a short circuit resistance,
Re of 0.0001, is connected in parallel with the certain
number of turns to simulate this fault as shown in Figure 25.
In this case, 10% of the HV winding turns is assumed to be
shorted. Figure 26 indicates that the magnitude of the FRA
response between 20 Hz and 2 kHz is slightly increased due
to this fault. The resonance and anti-resonance frequencies
between 40 kHz and 160 kHz are also affected.
C. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS
There are various statistical indicators used to analyze the
FRA results [33], [34]. The IEEE standard [35] recommended
using the correlation coefﬁcient (CC) for FRA interpretation.
In this paper, statistical indices such as the absolute sum of
logarithmic error (ASLE), standard deviation (SD), and sum
squared error (SSE) are also utilized. ASLE, SD, and SSE
could be more sensitive than CC to detect minor changes
in the FRA signature. According to [36], the criteria for
diagnosing winding displacement are below 0.9998 for the
CC, above 0.4 for the ASLE, and above 1.0 for the SD.
Three frequency sub-bands are considered in this paper’s
analysis because various faults affect the FRA signature
within these frequency ranges. Considered frequency ranges
are: low-frequency region (100 Hz < LF < 2 kHz),
VOLUME 9, 2021 70943
S. M. A. N. Al-Ameriet al.: Understanding Influence of Power Transformer Faults on Frequency Response Signature
FIGURE 28. Absolute sum logarithmic error for various transformer faults
within three sub-frequency ranges.
mid-frequency region (2 kHz < MF < 20 kHz) and the
high-frequency region (HF > 20 kHz). These are the fre-
quency ranges where the investigated faults have consider-
able effect on the FRA signature. The difference between the
normal and faulty responses is calculated at 326 points at the
LF range, 251 points at the MF range and 424 points at the HF
range. These statistical indicators are listed in Table 5 and
explained below.
1) CORRELATION COEFFICIENT
CC calculates the variation between two FRA traces X(i)
and Y(i), as given by (12). If the two responses are identical,
the result is 1; otherwise, it ranges between 0 and 1 based
on the two signals’ correlation level. However, CC is the
covariance normalization; so, it is not sensitive to identify
constant changes between two frequency responses [33].
CC(X,Y ) =
∑N
i=1 X (i)×Y (i)
√∑N
i=1 [X (i)]2 ×∑N
i=1 [Y (i)]2
(12)
Table 5 shows an agreement between normal and faulty
responses at low and mid-frequency regions. The values
of the CC are above 0.99 within these ranges for all fault
types. However, the CC detects the variation with values
at the high-frequency region between 0.99 and 0.98. Fig-
ure 27 shows an agreement between the responses at the
low-frequency and mid-frequency regions and division at the
high-frequency region. Therefore CC is sensitive to changes
in the high-frequency range. Compared to ASLE, SD, and
SSE, the CC is not highly recommended.
2) ABSOLUTE SUM LOGARITHMIC ERROR
ASLE is highly recommended in the latest studies as it
is reported to be more pertinent than the CC and SSE
for detecting the variation between transformer FRA signa-
tures [33], [37]. It can be calculated from:
ASLE(X,Y ) =
∑N

⏐⏐20log10Yi −20log10Xi

Table 5 shows that ASLE can detect the effect of inter-
disc fault, loss of clamping pressure, and short circuit fault
FIGURE 29. Standard deviation for various transformer faults within
three sub-frequency ranges.
over the entire frequency range, as the value of ASLE is
more than 0.53 for these faults. It also detects the variation
at high frequency range for the other investigated faults.
Figure 28 shows the sensitivity of this indicator to various
faults. As can be observed, ASLE cannot detect winding
axial displacement, radial deformation, and bushing fault
in the low-frequency and mid-frequency regions. However,
it clearly shows the effect of these faults at the high-frequency
region. According to these results, ASLE is a very sensitive
statistical indicator to the variation of the frequency responses
that have a linear correlation.
3) STANDARD DEVIATION
Previous studies reported that SD can detect changes of two
FRA signatures [24]. SD is calculated using (14).
SD(X,Y ) =
√
∑N
i=1 [Y (i)−X (i)]2
N −1 (14)
Typically, SD shows a similar trend as ASLE as can be
noticed in Table 5 and Figure 29. For the loss of clamping
pressure, ASLE shows more variation in the low-frequency
region than the high-frequency region, but SD shows a similar
variation level at both regions. The SD in short circuit fault
indicates an increment in the deviation at the low-frequency,
mid-frequency, and high-frequency regions. However, this
increment is slightly shown by using the ASLE. Hence,
the SD can also be highly recommended for the interpretation
of the FRA signatures.
4) SUM SQUARE ERROR
The SSE is sensitive to considerable variation and is not
sensitive to differences less than one. It can be calculated
from:
SSE =
∑N
i=1 (Y (i)−X (i))2
N (15)
SSE sensitivity to detect faults such as inter-disc fault
and short circuit faults is shown in Figure 30 which reveals
that SSE can detect the deviation between normal and faulty
signatures.

5) DISCUSSIONS
A summary of the effect of each examined fault on the FRA
signature is shown in Table 6. This table is created to list the
effect of various transformer faults on the FRA signature. The
table can be used to initiate appropriate standards for power
transformer FRA signature interpretation. Table 6 shows that
the inter-disc fault that is simulated by a 10% reduction in
the number of discs, has no effect on the frequency response
at the LF region while it affects the signature at the MF and
the HF regions. The axial winding displacement which is
simulated by a 10% increment in the capacitance Csh, and
the mutual inductance Mkm, has no effect on the signature
within the LF and MF regions while it affects the signature in
the HF region. The radial fault is simulated by reducing the
capacitance to ground. Results show that radial fault affects
the FRA signature at the HF region through an increase in
the magnitude. Bushing fault is simulated by reducing the
bushing capacitance by 50%, and the results show its impact
in the HF region, as summarized in Table 6. The losses of
winding clamping shows an effect on the entire frequency
range. The short circuit fault affects the FRA signature within
the MF and HF regions.
Eventually, this study proposed a simpliﬁed transformer
model and simulated several faults that can be detected
using the FRA technique. The motivation behind using this
methodology is the difﬁculty of applying various destructive
mechanical faults to the power transformers to study their
impacts on the FRA signature. Comparison of the FRA sig-
natures obtained using the simulation model and the prac-
tical measurement indicates the robustness of the proposed
simulation model. Obtained results for axial displacement
agree well with the results published in [21]. There is also
a good agreement with the measurement results published
in [22], [38]. Analytical results show that statistical indicators
are not consistent in revealing all types of faults.
IV. CONCLUSION
This paper is aimed to provide a better understanding to the
FRA signatures using simulation and statistical indicators.
A 33/11 kV 30 MV A transformer circuit model is proposed
to study the impact of various faults on the FRA signature.
The model parameters such as series resistance Rs, series
capacitance Cs, and mutual inductance Mkm are calculated
using complex equations based on the transformer physical
dimensions. The model sensitivity analysis shows that the
simulated FRA signature is sensitive to the variations in the
circuit parameters, which gives more conﬁdence in using the
VOLUME 9, 2021 70945
S. M. A. N. Al-Ameriet al.: Understanding Influence of Power Transformer Faults on Frequency Response Signature
simulation model to mimic real faults. Results show that the
inter-disk fault affects the FRA response at the mid- and high-
frequency regions. Axial winding displacement shows an
impact on the high-frequency region, which is similar to the
effect of radial deformation and winding bushing fault. The
loss of clamping pressure shows an effect over the entire fre-
quency range. The impact of short circuit fault is noticeable
at the mid-and high-frequency regions. Statistical indicators,
CC, ASLE, SD, and SSE, are sensitive to the variations in
the FRA signature. Results show that the ASLE has a good
performance in detecting small variations. However, there is
no one single indicator that can detect all fault types. Results
recommend the use of all investigated indicators in three-
sub-frequency ranges.

SALEM MGAMMAL AWADH NASSER
AL-AMERI received the B.Eng. degree in mecha-
tronics engineering from Asia Paciﬁc University
(APU), in 2012, and the M.Eng. degree in electri-
cal engineering (power) and the Ph.D. degree from
Universiti Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia (UTHM),
in 2016 and 2020, respectively. He currently holds
a postdoctoral position with Universiti Tun Hus-
sein Onn Malaysia. His research interest includes
transformers condition monitoring.
MUHAMMAD SAUFI KAMARUDIN(Member,
IEEE) received the bachelor’s degree in elec-
trical engineering and the Master of Engineer-
ing degree in electrical power from Universiti
Teknologi Malaysia, in 2003 and 2005, respec-
tively, and the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineer-
ing (high voltage) from Cardiff University, U.K.,
in 2014. Since 2003, he has been serving as an
Academic Staff with Universiti Tun Hussein Onn
Malaysia (UTHM), where he is currently an Asso-
ciate Professor and the Head of the Electrical Engineering Department,
Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering. He worked extensively
on SF6 alternatives. He has also worked on lightning impulse tests and
ﬁnite element modeling. He is also a Professional Engineer, registered with
the Board of Engineers, Malaysia (BEM), and a Corporate Member of the
Institution of Engineers, Malaysia (IEM). His research interest includes gas
breakdown and discharges.
MOHD FAIROUZ MOHD YOUSOF (Member,
IEEE) received the B.Eng. and M.Eng. degrees
from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia and the Ph.D.
degree from The University of Queensland, Aus-
tralia, in 2015. From 2018 to 2019, he was
appointed as a Visiting Researcher with the TNB
Research. Since 2019, he has been a Principal
Consultant with Xair Energy Sdn. Bhd. He is cur-
rently a Lecturer with the Department of Electrical
Power Engineering, Universiti Tun Hussein Onn
Malaysia (UTHM). His main research interest includes condition-based
monitoring and assessment of high-voltage equipment, speciﬁcally power
transformer and rotating machine. He is also a Registered Member of the
Board of Engineers Malaysia (BEM) and a member of the Malaysian Society
for Engineering and Technology (MySET).
ALI A. SALEM (Member, IEEE) was born in
Sana’a, Yemen, in March 1985. He received
the M.Eng. degree in electrical power engineer-
ing from University Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia
(UTHM), in 2016, where he is currently pursuing
the Ph.D. degree in high voltage with the Faculty
of Electrical Engineering. His research interest
includes the dynamic arc modeling of pollution
ﬂashover on high-voltage outdoor insulators.
FAHD A. BANAKHR (Senior Member, IEEE)
received the degree in electronic and industrial
control engineering from the University of Not-
tingham, U.K., the master’s degree in electronic
instrumentation systems from The University of
Manchester, U.K., and the Ph.D. degree in sensors
and instrumentation engineering from Loughbor-
ough University, U.K. He is currently the Director
of the Yanbu Research Center, Royal Commission
of Yanbu, Saudi Arabia. He is also a Visiting
Lecturer in smart and intelligent instrumentation with Nottingham Trent
University, U.K. His research interests include intelligent and smart sensors,
intelligent control systems, the Internet of Things, and artiﬁcial intelligence.
He is a member of ISA, the IEEE Instrumentation and Measurements
Society, the IEEE Control Systems (Intelligent Control Systems Technical
Committee), and the Institute of Measurements and Control, U.K. He was
awarded the High V oltage Association Student Excellence Award from the
IEEE International Power Modulator and High V oltage Conference, in 2012,
and the Sir Martin Award for academic and non-academic achievement from
Loughborough University, in 2011. He is also the Chairman of the IEEE IoT
and Harmonization Middle East Sub Group, and the Vice Chairman of the
IEEEE Smart Transducers for IoT Working Group.
MOHAMED I. MOSAAD received the B.Sc.
and M.Sc. degrees in electrical engineering from
Zagazig University, Egypt, and the Ph.D. degree
in electrical engineering from Cairo University,
Egypt. He is currently an Associate Professor with
the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engi-
neering Technology, YIC, Saudi Arabia. He is the
author of more than 70 high-ranked journal arti-
cles and conference papers. His research interests
include power system stability, control, and opti-
mization, and renewable energy. He is also the Editor-in Chief of IJES.
He is also a Reviewer of the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON POWER DELIVERY, IEEE
TRANSACTIONS ON ENERGY CONVERSION, IET Electric Power ApplicationJour-
nal, IET Generation, Transmission & DistributionJournal, The Journal of
Engineering (IET), IET Energy System Integration,Journal of Cleaner Pro-
duction, Electric Power Components and Systems, theInternational Journal
of Industrial Electronics and Drives (IJIED), IEEE ACCESSJournal, Electric
Power Systems Research,Energies, Alexandria Engineering Journal,Ain
Shams Engineering Journal,Asian Journal of Control, and theInternational
Journal of Energy Engineering (IJEE).
A. ABU-SIADA(Senior Member, IEEE) received
the B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees from Ain Shams
University, Egypt, in 1998, and the Ph.D. degree
from Curtin University, Australia, in 2004, all in
electrical engineering. He is currently the Head of
electrical and computer engineering with Curtin
University. His research interests include power
electronics, power system stability, condition
monitoring, and power quality. He is also the Vice-
Chair of the IEEE Computation Intelligence Soci-
ety and WA Chapter. He is also the Editor-in-Chief of the International
Journal of Electrical and Electronic Engineeringand a regular reviewer for
various IEEE TRANSACTIONS.
